title: Struggling mum who ‘flipped’ and stabbed alcoholic son spared jail
text:

A dedicated mum who stabbed her adult son after battling with his alcoholic behaviour has been cleared of attempted murder.

Jacqueline Bywater, 58, attacked her son James, 37, and herself with a knife in despair over his heavy drinking in her home.

Bywater lashed out after years of trying to help her son who was verbally abusive and stole from her, Teesside Crown Court heard on Monday.

He had superficial wounds after she cut him on the chest and stomach on June 2, but later died from unrelated causes linked to his drinking.

Bywater was arrested on suspicion of attempted murder and was behind bars for seven weeks, a charge of which she has now been cleared.

Mr Bywater's drawn out history of addiction - and strain it put on his family - caused his mother to suffer serious bouts of depression and anxiety.

She self-harmed and attempted to commit suicide three times, Gazette Live reported.

(Image: Google)

Judge Stephen Ashurst told her: "Like all parents, you loved your children, and James despite his many difficulties.

"You were simply unable to cope with his behaviour.

"It was not only eccentric and excessive but compounded by his drinking. He presented problems at home that any other parent would have found impossible to deal with.

"You stuck by James through thick and thin.

"So preoccupied and overwhelmed were you by his difficulties that you failed to appreciate how your own mental health had been affected.

"All parents are forgiving. You had to forgive an awful lot in terms of the disruptive and often upsetting behaviour of your son.

"He treated you very badly and failed to appreciate how much you cared for him."

The troubled son had longstanding issues with alcohol, resulting in frequent verbal argument with his mum.

Shortly after Bywater attacked James, she was heard shouting with blood on her hands and the kitchen floor at about 2pm.

She called the police saying she had stabbed her son and herself, said prosecutor Rachel Masters.

Mr Bywater’s puncture wounds were cleaned and closed at hospital.

He later said he did not want his mother prosecuted, and died shortly after from "matters entirely unrelated to this incident".

When Bywater, of Westfield Court, Redcar, was detained she denied attempted murder.

She was formally acquitted of this charge after the prosecution accepted her guilty plea to the lesser charge of unlawful wounding - her first conviction.

Zahra Baqri, defending, said the sleep-deprived mum acted impulsively amid serious depression when she saw her son drinking heavily.

She said: “She flipped when she saw the state that her son was in. She said he was killing himself with alcohol abuse.

"She proceeded to cut her own arm. She told doctors she wanted to frighten her son in a desperate attempt for him to stop drinking."

Mental health agencies and support workers who tried to help Mr Byswater fight his drug and alcohol addictions were unsuccessful.

Ms Baqri added: "The defendant did everything to help him. She was a dedicated mother, so much so that she hardly found time for herself.

"The cause of James' passing was as a direct consequence of his addictions."

In the days leading up to the incident, Bywater had sought ‘refuge’ in her bedroom and was referred to the crisis team by her GP.

She had serious depressive episodes and suicidal thoughts as she was ‘unable to cope’.

But a consultant psychiatrist assessed her as very low risk of reoffending.

Judge Ashurst ruled the case as ‘exceptional’ where the mother had reacted to extreme circumstances.

He told Bywater: "You took a knife to James at a time when your levels of despair were especially high.

"You did not intend to kill him and although you bitterly regret picking up that kitchen knife, the injuries you caused in wounding James were not particularly serious.

"I make it clear to you that I'm not going to order you to return to custody today."

Bywater was given a one-year prison sentence suspended for 18 months with 24 days’ rehabilitation activity "to assist you in rebuilding your life after this very traumatic event".
